Top-3 Similar Questions: so_43097924: PDF generated in Linux does not open in Windows - using enscript
ul_470364: How shall I generate a pdf file instead of a ps file using enscript?
Top-3 Scripts:
ul_470364: enscript -B -P <PDF_PRINTER_NAME> code/bloom.c -p myfile.ps

-P name, --printer=name
Spool the output to the printer name.

-p file, --output=file
Leave the output to file file. If the file is `-', enscript sends the output to the standard output stdout.

enscript file -o - | ps2pdf - output.pdf

enscript -2 -r -j --font=Times-Roman11 --word-wrap --mark-wrapped=arrow '%f' && sleep 2 && evince ~/PDF/_stdin_.pdf

- The `%f` designates the filename parameter.    
- The `&& sleep 2 && evince ~/PDF/_stdin_.pdf` commands will wait two seconds for the print job to finish, then run the Evince PDF viewer to display the file _stdin_.pdf you just generated in the user’s PDF subdirectory.

Explanations about Options.-r: Print in the landscape mode; rotate page 90 degrees.
Explanations about Options.-2:
Specify how many columns each page have. With the long option --columns=num you
 can specify more than 9 columns per page.
Explanations about Options.--font:
Select a font that is used for the body text. The default body font is Courier10,
 unless multicolumn landscape printing mode is selected, in which case the default
 font is Courier7.
Explanations about Options.--word-wrap: Wrap long lines from word boundaries.

ul_618616: $ gs -dBATCH -dNOPAUSE -q -sDEVICE=pdfwrite -sOutputFile=temp.pdf test.pdf
   **** Error: ICCbased space /N value does not match the ICC profile.

Explanations about Options.-sDEVICE: Selects an alternate initial output device, as described above.
Explanations about Options.-dNOPAUSE:
Disables the prompt and pause at the end of each page. This may be desirable for
 applications where another program is driving Ghostscript.
Explanations about Options.-q:
Quiet startup: suppress normal startup messages, and also do the equivalent of
 -dQUIET.
Explanations about Options.-sOutputFile:
Selects an alternate output file (or pipe) for the initial output device, as
 described above.
